Award.AwardTitle: Ideas Lab Collaborative Research: Using Natural Odor Stimuli to Crack the Olfactory Code
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project was developed during a NSF Ideas Lab on "Cracking the Olfactory Code" and is jointly funded by the Chemistry of Life Processes program in the Chemistry Division, the Mathematical Biology program in the Division of Mathematical Sciences, the Physics of Living Systems program in the Physics Division, the Neural Systems Cluster in the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems, the Division of Biological Infrastructure, and the Division of Emerging Frontiers. The sense of smell is essential for maintaining quality of life in humans, and its decline can be an important harbinger of neurodegenerative disease. Moreover, since nearly all animals aside from primates rely on olfaction for most survival functions, understanding chemical sensing has immense practical value, for example, in the control of agricultural pests or in training animals to detect odors relevant for bomb, drug and cancer detection. In spite of its importance, the understanding of olfaction lags far behind the other senses, which is in part due to the lack of understanding of the physical space of odors. The understanding of the neural bases of vision and audition were greatly advanced by investigations of the physical dimensions of visual and auditory stimuli. It is therefore likely that a similar in-depth investigation of odor space - how natural odors occur and the backgrounds against which they must be detected - will reveal a new depth of richness of neural representations of odors in the brain. Insects such as the fruit fly and honey bee are excellent models for this research because of the accessibility of their central nervous systems, because of their ease of use under controlled laboratory conditions, and because of the functional similarity of how odors are processed in insect and mammalian brains. This research will characterize how odor flowers and fruits with respect to behavioral value for honey bees (food) and fruit flies (food and egg laying sites). Further monitoring of neural activity in early and later stage processing in the brain, when combined with computational modeling, will reveal significantly richer neural representations than have heretofore been described. This new understanding stands to have an impact on understanding how healthy brains encode sensations and memories of odors and how brains fail under disease conditions. It will also have an impact on understanding how the sense of smell may be built into engineered devices. Finally, both insects are also of economic importance to agriculture for crop pollination (honey bees) and damage to fruit (fruit flies). The PIs will teach and work with undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral students and especially recruit students from underrepresented groups in science.

This research will quantitatively characterize the real-world statistics of multi-component natural odor scenes and investigate how they drive behavior and processing in several brain regions. The focus will be on honey bee as well as fruit fly adults and larva as models, where it will be possible to characterize a library of ethologically relevant natural odors associated with a diversity of behavioral outputs. The work will begin by quantitatively characterizing the detailed statistical properties of natural odor scenes in defined ethological contexts. This will build on the rich literature on identified natural odors in insects and mammals. Naturally occurring plant and fruit odor samples from the natural environments of each insect will be collected and chemically analyzed. Nonlinear dimensionality reduction techniques and approaches based on sparse coding will determine the dimensions of odor space that are most salient for behavioral decisions. Such a quantitative deconstruction of the sensory input would be unprecedented in olfactory neuroscience, and should allow the PIs to effectively and comprehensively drive olfactory circuits for the first time. The hypothesis is that the stimulus dimensions that are most behaviorally relevant to the animal will be most efficiently extracted by the olfactory system. Synthetic odor blends will be specially constructed to vary along relevant sensory dimensions, to probe neural codes and adaptive behaviors in the olfactory system. As in research on the visual system, analysis of such evoked neural responses using statistical methods that take into account natural odor statistics will reveal novel olfactory computations and behaviors that have been previously inaccessible. The project will generate datasets of immediate use and importance to scientists in theoretical biology and mathematics, engineering and biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goals of this project were to understand how animal brains process chemical information from the environment and use it to guide useful behaviors that promote survival. An additional goal was to understand how these processes are affected by prior sensory experience, especially experiences that occur early in life. The odors that animals experience in natural environments are typically complex mixtures of many different individual chemicals. This project specifically asked whether the circuit architecture of olfactory areas of the brain may be adapted to process complex chemical mixtures arising from natural odor sources, as opposed to individual pure chemicals (which is what has more typically been used in laboratory research). We investigated these questions in the fly Drosophila melanogaster, because it has a numerically compact, well-mapped olfactory system, and we can use genetic tools to measure and manipulate neural activity in defined neuronal populations. 

Using novel imaging strategies for measuring near complete patterns of neural activity in higher olfactory processing areas, we found that experimentally observed patterns of neural activity evoked by odors consistently diverged from the predictions of computational models that assume unstructured (i.e. random) integration of odor inputs by the brain. This finding suggests that neural integration of odor inputs occurs in a structured manner. To investigate if this structure might be adapted to natural odors, we determined how the patterns of neural activity elicited by complex mixtures of naturally co-occurring chemicals compare to those elicited by similarly complex mixtures of random (non co-occurring) chemicals. We observed that, for natural mixtures, the patterns of activity generated by the component chemicals and the mixture were more similar to one another, as compared to the “unnatural” random mixture. This result suggests that the brain may more readily recognize incomplete or partial combinations of chemicals that are naturally co-occurring as signaling a natural odor object, with the tradeoff being that their component chemicals may not be as easily distinguishable from one another as compared to random collections of odors.

This project also investigated how natural sensory experiences in early life shape our perception as adults. Both mammals and Drosophila show altered behavioral responses toward an odor when they are raised in an environment where that odor is very abundant. However, past studies demonstrating this effect exposed animals to extremely high concentrations of pure chemicals, a situation not commonly encountered in the natural world. Here, we evaluated how sensory coding and odor-dependent behaviors are affected when animals are chronically exposed to odors under plausible naturalistic conditions. Exposure to a specific natural odor source in early life -- for instance, banana – significantly increased the speed and frequency with which flies later entered a trap baited with that odor source. Analysis of the dynamics of the flies’ odor search behavior revealed that all flies, regardless of early odor experience, detected and navigated to the baited trap equally well, but banana-exposed flies made the decision to enter the trap earlier and more often. In addition, in flies that were exposed in early life to defined odors, electrophysiological measurements showed that odor responses in neurons mediating the earliest stages of olfactory processing were relatively stable, despite being chronically active for days. These results indicate that odor exposure in early life under naturalistic conditions can trigger changes in behavior, and these changes take the form of an increased response towards the odor. This result contrasts with prior studies that generally report a decrease in aversiveness toward an odor. Our behavioral and electrophysiological results also argue against the idea that the principal effect of chronic odor exposure is a change in the sensitivity of the first stages of olfactory processing, as has been previously suggested. Rather, our results are more consistent with odor experience in early life impacting the meaning of the odor to the animal, for instance, by increasing its appetitiveness and/or decreasing its perceived associated risk, and thereby lowering the behavioral threshold to enter the trap. We propose that such changes in perceived stimulus quality caused by odor experience are likely to be encoded in higher olfactory areas in the brain.

This project has funded or partially funded one postdoc, three graduate students, and seven undergraduate students, and supported the training of several underrepresented groups, including six women (1 postdoc, 2 graduate, 3 undergraduate); one first-generation college student; and two community college students. Understanding how any system, including the brain, efficiently encodes and decodes naturally occurring chemical information has important implications for controlling biotic interactions in ecosystems, for agriculture and food security, for national security, and for health and disease. In addition, understanding how olfactory experiences in early life impact how we perceive odors in adult life, including odors from novel foods and environments, has important implications for understanding the factors that contribute to cultural differences in how humans perceive the world more broadly.
